channel.title: St Helena Island, Queensland
channel.description: Recent content on St Helena Island, Queensland

item.title: Thematic Analysis
item.description: The Analysis This thematic analysis focussed on the history of the St Helena Penal Establishment located in Moreton Bay, Queensland. The sources gathered, once analysed, provide themes that reveal areas for further study. The data can be added to existing data to create an easily found and accessible (not behind a paywall), dataset, that is open access (not one program specific) and reproducible - a FAIR dataset. Key Repositories Key repositories used to access sources

item.title: Harvesting data from the web
item.description: The dataset that I have created involves the St Helena Penal Establishment prisoner cemetery. I have used as many online sources, which were not behind a pay wall, to provide as much information about the buried prisoners; to go beyond a mere list of names and death dates. The dataset aims to humanise the name and number of as many buried prisoners as possible. It must be noted however, that the names of those inmates buried at St Helena used in this dataset may be subject to change, and additions, or subtractions, made which were not available at the time of compilation.

item.title: Historic Image Analysis
item.description: Aerial photograph of St Helena prison Brisbane City Council (1920) Aerial photograph of St Helena prison in the 1920s [photograph], Brisbane Images, Brisbane City Council website, © Brisbane Images, Brisbane City Council. This Copyright has expired. This image may be reproduced with acknowledgement, accessed 12 October 2022. This aerial photograph of the St Helena Penal Establishment focuses on the buildings surrounding the stockade, as the island is much larger than shown.

item.title: Thematic Analysis Discussion
item.description: Analysis Discussion The codebook generated in Taguette clearly identifies five major tags which have far more highlights than other tags. I would have to say that some of the minor tags could possibly be merged with larger tags, for example, the crops tag could be merged with farm work, and on entry to penal establishment could be merged with the descriptions tag. I have combined here, warders and goings on behind closed doors because they had the same prominent theme, corruption, involving warders and prison gang members.

item.title: Research design page
item.description: Research question What is the contribution of research in the digital humanities to the production and dissemination of public ‘stories’ or interpretations about aspects of local community history and cultural heritage? Drawing on a series of related case studies, illustrate how these tools and methods can aid historical scholarship. Introduction The aim of this project is to explore how tools used in the digital humanities help to produce, interpret, and share the history of St Helena Island (Noogoon), Queensland, in the period 1867-1932.

item.title: Discussion and conclusions
item.description: The aim of this project was to explore how tools used in the digital humanities help to produce, interpret, and share the history of St Helena Island (Noogoon), Queensland, in the period 1867-1932. The project required me to create a dataset from sources in multiple repositories and thematically analyse them, analyse historic images, and display some of the areas of interest in a map created in QGis. By creating a dataset, I added information to the existing data relating to the prisoner’s cemetery on St Helena Island.

item.title: References
item.description: A paying guest (12 February 1911) ‘Penal Establishment and health resort: High life and hell’, Truth, accessed 1 October 2022. A paying guest (5 February 1911) ‘Penal Establishment or Health Resort? High Life or Hell, Which?’, Truth, accessed 31 October 2022. Alfredson G (1983) ‘St Helena Island - A Changing Pattern of Exploitation?’, Australian Archaeology, 17(1):79–86, doi:[10.1080/03122417.1983.12092912](doi:%5B10.1080/03122417.1983.12092912){.uri}. Ancestry.com (n.d.) Queensland, Australia, Death Inquest Index, 1859-1897, Ancestry.com website, accessed 3 September 2022.

item.title: Data Dictionary
item.description: Alias names used by the inmate other than their legal names where none is provided use na Cause of death the cause of death stated on death certificate for each individual where none is provided use na Christian name legal name where none is provided use na Crime the crime that was committed by the inmate where none is provided use na Death Date year - where none is provided use 0 (zero) - numerals only

item.title: Mapping your data
item.description: St Helena Island (Noogoon), Moreton Bay Queensland This is a map of the points of interest on St Helena Island, Queensland created using Qgis

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.
